Observation: The stack operates on a Last-In-First-Out (LIFO) principle. The last

Exercise7  Date:08-10-2025 
 
Aim: To write a C program to create a singly linked list and implement insertion 
operations at the beginning, end and at a specific position of the list.  
Code: 
 

 
 
Output: 
 
 
 
Observation: 
The function insertAtBeginning() inserts a new node at the start of 
the list by changing the headpointer. The function insertAtEnd() 
traverses the linked list to the last node and adds the new node at 
the end.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

 
 
Exercise8  Date:15-10-2025 
Aim: To write a C program to implement a singly linked list that supports the 
following operations: insertion at the beginning, insertion at the end, insertion at 
a specific position, deletion from the beginning, deletion from the end, and 
deletion from a specific position. 
Code: 
 
 

 
 
 
 
Output: 
 
 
Observation: The program successfully demonstrates the basic operations of a 
singly linked list. It allows insertion at the beginning, end, and any specific 
position, as well as deletion from the beginning, end, and a chosen position. The 
output confirms that the linked list structure dynamically adjusts its nodes 
according to the operations performed, showing how linked lists provide fle xibility 
in memory management compared to arrays.

Aim: To perform different traversals on a binary tree, use the diagram given

order traversal sequences. Also ,implement a function to find and print the height 
of the  tree. 
Code: 
 
 

 
 
 
Output: 
 
 
 
Observation: 
This program builds a binarytree with several nodes and shows different 
ways to visit every node, called traversals (in-order, pre-order, 
post-order). The function getHeight calculates how many steps the 
longest path from the root to a leaf takes, which is called the height 
of the tree.

Exercise11  Date:24-10-2025 
Aim: To write a C program for the BubbleSort algorithm. 
Code: 
 
Output: 
 
 
Observation: The algorithm checks each pair of adjacent elements and swaps 
them if needed, thus pushing the largest element to the end in each pass. The use 
of the isSwap flag provides an optimization by terminating early if the array 
becomes sorted before completing all passes.
